title: Welcome to Proceeds of Crime
body:
Money laundering and terrorist financing are considered to be international problems. Money laundering in Canada alone is estimated to be in the billions of dollars. To help combat this criminal activity the Government of Canada has developed the Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act (PCMLTFA).

The Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA) enforces this Act as it relates to the movement of currency and monetary instruments across borders. While enforcing this act, BSO’s must also apply appropriate legislation, policies and procedures pertaining to search and seizures.

The following lesson will prepare you in understanding and recognizing money laundering and terrorist financing activities, as well as applying the appropriate legislation pertaining to search and seizures.

title: Assessment
body: At the end of each module, there is a brief learning check to review key points. As a final assessment, the course includes four case studies.

title: Confirming Your Participation
body: To be able to confirm your participation in ESS My Learning, you must have reviewed all elements of the course and have completed all of the activities.

title: Required Resources
body:
To complete this course you will need to use or refer to the following resources. Please open them now and bookmark them for quick and easy access:

  • Justice of Canada website:
    • Proceeds of Crime (Monetary Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act
    • Cross Border Currency and Monetary Instruments Reporting Regulations
  • Criminal Code:
    • Section 83.01 - providing, making available, etc., property or services for terrorist purposes
    • Section 354 – possession of property obtained by crime
    • Section 462.31 - laundering proceeds of crime
  • CBSA External Forms – available on Atlas :
    • E677  - Cross Border Currency or Monetary Instruments Report – Individual
    • E667 – Cross Border Currency or Monetary Instruments Report – General
    • E668- Cross Border Currency or Monetary Instruments Report – Made by Person in Charge of Conveyance
  • Operational Bulletin:
    • PRG-2012-57
    • PRG-2012-58 – Suspected Proceeds of Crime Indicator Guidelines
  • CBSA Enforcement Manual (EN Manual):
    • Part 6, Chapter 1 (Arrest and Detention)
    • Part 2, Chapter 2: Cross-Border Currency and Monetary Instruments Reporting
    • Part 2, Chapter 2, section Establishing Proceeds of Crime Criteria Under the Criminal Code
  • Officer Reference Booklet

title: Learning Objectives
body:
After completing this course, you will be able to:

  • Define money laundering and terrorist financing.
  • Recognize money laundering indicators and techniques.
  • Identify the appropriate legislation pertaining to a search and seizure, when there is reasonable grounds to believe the traveller did not declare his currency ($10,000 CAD or greater).
  • Identify the appropriate legislation pertaining to a search and seizure, when there is reasonable grounds to suspect the traveller is involved in money laundering and/or financing of terrorist activities

title: Question 1 of 8
body: Which part of the PCMLTFA is the CBSA responsible for?
instruction: Select an answer and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. CBSA is responsible for Part 2 of the PCMLTFA.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. CBSA is responsible for Part 2 of the PCMLTFA.

title: Question 1 of 6
body: What section of the PCMLTFA gives BSOs the authority to seize currency on reasonable grounds to believe the currency was not reported?
instruction: Select an answer and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. Section 18 of the PCMLTFA gives BSOs the right to seize currency on reasonable grounds to believe the currency was not reported.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. Section 18 of the PCMLTFA gives BSOs the right to seize currency on reasonable grounds to believe the currency was not reported.

title: Non-Reported Currency
body:
As per subsection 18(1) of the PCMLTFA, if an officer believes on reasonable grounds that subsection 12(1) (failure to report currency equal to or greater than $10,000) has been contravened, the officer may seize as forfeit the currency or monetary instruments.

All currency/MI seizures pursuant to the PCMLTFA must be completed on a K19C in ICES.

 

What if you suspect the non-reported currency to be proceeds of crime?

For seizing purposes, a non-report and suspected proceeds of crime are not separate offences. You seize on reasonable grounds to believe that the currency was not reported, and then decide not to offer terms of release (level 4), as you suspect the currency is proceeds of crime.

 

In 2018, there was a key change done to the PCMLTFA Act. Section 13 was repealed, more specifically c.27,s.174. The previous version of the PCMLTFA section 13 was effective from 2002-12-31 until 2018-12-12.

The following chart provides an overview of your authority when seizing currency and monetary instruments under PCMLTFA.

The officer must have reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a contravention of the PCMLTFA.

Currency/MI not reported AND equal to or greater than $10,000 CAD

BSO seizes currency/MI under the PCMLTFA

BSO has reasonable ground to suspect the currency/MI is proceeds of crime or terrorist financing

NO

Seize as Level 1, 2 or 3 with terms of release

YES

Seize as Level 4, no terms of release

title: Levels of Penalty
body: There are four levels of penalty that exist when a BSO seizes currency or monetary instruments.
instruction: Select the tabs to learn more.

_items.title: Level 1
_items.body:
Details:

  • Has not concealed the currency;
  • Has made a full disclosure of the facts upon discovery; and
  • Has no previous PCMLTFA seizures.

Penalty Amount: $250.

_items.title: Level 2
_items.body:
Details:

  • Currency is concealed other than by use of a false compartment in a conveyance (e.g. body packing, concealed in luggage, clothing etc.);
  • Has made a false statement with respect to the currency; or,
  • Has a previous PCMLTFA seizure

Penalty Amount: $2,500.

_items.title: Level 3
_items.body:
Details:

  • Currency is concealed by using a false compartment in a conveyance; or
  • Previous Level 2 or Level 3 PCMLTFA seizure for any type of concealment or for making a false statement with respect to the currency

Penalty Amount: $5,000.

_items.title: Level 4
_items.body:
Details:

  • Under the PCMLTFA, BSOs may seize non-reported $/MI  when they have reasonable grounds to suspect the funds are proceeds of crime; and
  • No terms of release are offered.

Penalty Amount:  Not Applicable. No terms of release offered

_items.title: Seized Currency
_items.body:
Level 1, 2, and 3

The traveller has a choice of paying the penalty to retrieve the seized currency or abandoning the currency.

  • Release upon payment
    As per subsection 18(2) of the PCMLTFA, the officer shall, on payment of a penalty in the prescribed amount, return the seized currency or monetary instruments to the individual from whom they were seized or to the lawful owner.
     

    The penalty cannot be paid using the seized currency.

  • Abandoning the currency
    If the traveller does not want to pay the penalty, the currency will remain under customs seizure as per subsection 18(2) of the PCMLTFA and be forfeited to the Crown.

Level 4

The fourth level pertains to proceeds of crime and terrorist financing .

There will be no return of seized currency or monetary instruments when the officer has reasonable grounds to suspect that the currency or monetary instruments are proceeds of crime within the meaning of subsection 462.3(1) of the Criminal Code or funds for use in the financing of terrorist activities.

title: Question 1 of 5
body: Bulk cash smuggling across an international border is a common form of money laundering.
instruction: Select true or false and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. Bulk cash smuggling across an international border is a common form of money laundering.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. Bulk cash smuggling across an international border is a common form of money laundering.

_graphic.alt: Man in truck hanging off of window

title: Case Study 1: The Gambler
body: A BSO is working at a PIL booth at Niagara Falls Rainbow Bridge POE, in Ontario. An American citizen and resident states he is coming to the Niagara Fallsview Casio. He declares $20,000 U.S. and says: “I’ll be having some fun at the Black Jack tables tonight!”. The BSO refers the traveller to complete the proper currency declaration form.

title: Money Laundering Legislation
body:
The Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA) is responsible for enforcement of Part 2 of the PCMLTFA, which relates to the physical movement of currency and monetary instruments across the border.

This act, in collaboration with other legislation and regulations, has been put in place to help combat money laundering and terrorist financing activities. Take a moment to review the main objectives of these legislations below.

Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act

The object of this Act is to implement specific measures to detect and deter money laundering and the financing of terrorist activities and to facilitate the investigation and prosecution of money laundering offences and terrorist activity financing offences.

Cross-Border Currency and Monetary Instruments Reporting Regulations

The CBCMIRR establish the threshold amount for currency reporting at $10,000 CAD or its equivalent after conversion, the general manner of reporting, retention, the prescribed amount of the penalties, and administrative details.

Cross-Border Currency and Monetary Instruments Reporting Policy and Procedures

This policy provides guidelines to CBSA officers in the event of imports and exports of currency or monetary instruments totalling $10,000 CAD or greater. This policy applies to all CBSA officers in all modes of transportation.

title: Background
body:
Money laundering is a serious criminal offence entailing the illegal movement of funds, estimated to be billions of dollars, through Canada each year.

The impact of organized crime and money laundering goes beyond easily recognized consequences such as violence and economic losses to include less visible social costs.

As previously mentioned, to help combat criminal activities the Government of Canada has developed the Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act (PCMLTFA).

As a result , currency and monetary instruments of a value equal to or greater than $10,000 Canadian being imported to and exported from Canada must be reported to a Border Services Officer.

title: The Big Picture
body: For a better understanding of your role in the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing, watch the video below.

title: Money Laundering
body: The term money laundering may differ from one organization to another.
instruction: Select the following organizations to view their definition of money laundering.

_items.backBody: The United Nations defines money laundering as “an act or attempted act to disguise the source of money or assets derived from criminal activity”.

For the RCMP, money laundering:

  • converts proceeds of crime to another less suspicious form.
  • conceals the criminal origins and ownership of funds.
  • creates a legitimate explanation for the source of funds.

Money laundering is the process by which “dirty money” generated by criminal activities is converted into assets that cannot be easily traced back to their illegal origins.

- Enforcement Manual, Part 2, Chapter 2.

title: Monetary Instruments and Currency
body: In the course of your duties, you will encounter currency and monetary instruments that may or may not be reported to you.
instruction: Select the items to learn more about them.

_items.backBody:
Monetary instruments means the following instruments in bearer form or in such other form as title to them passes on delivery, namely,

a) securities, including stocks, bonds, debentures and treasury bills; and

b) negotiable instruments, including bank drafts, cheques, promissory notes, travellers’ cheques and money orders, other than warehouse receipts or bills of lading

- Cross Border Currency and Monetary Instruments Reporting Regulations

 

In case of monetary instruments, for greater certainty, this definition does not apply to securities or negotiable instruments that bear restrictive endorsements or a stamp for the purposes of clearing or are made payable to a named person and have not been endorsed.

Currency (cash) means:

a) coins referred to in section 7 of the Currency Act,

b) notes issued by the Bank of Canada pursuant to the Bank of Canada Act that are intended for circulation in Canada, or

c) coins or bank notes of countries other than Canada

- Cross Border Currency and Monetary Instruments Reporting Regulations

What else should you know about currency?

  • When encountering damaged or partially torn bank notes, CBSA officers must calculate the amount based on the face value of these bank notes, regardless of the proportion of each bank note that remains intact. It is not the responsibility of CBSA to determine the value of the damaged/torn portion of the currency being imported/exported.
  • Non-circulation coins, such as gold/silver coins or any other collectable coins, are not defined as currency under PCMLTFA and, as such, there is no obligation to report the importation or exportation of such items pursuant to the PCMLTFA. However, these non-circulation coins must be reported upon importation pursuant to the Customs Act.
  • Crypto currencies such as Bitcoin are not captured within the definition of currency or monetary instruments under the CBCMIRR Therefore, there is no obligation to report crypto currencies.

title: Reporting Legislation
body:
When it comes to reporting currency and monetary instruments, section 12 of the PCMLTFA and the CBCMIRR requires that every person report the importation/exportation of currency or monetary instruments equal to or greater than $10,000 CAD. This amount includes Canadian or foreign currency - or a combination of both.

 

There is no restriction on the amount of currency or monetary instruments a person can import/export through the border, but it must be reported if the value is equal or greater than $10.000 CAD.

 

Take a moment to review the PCMLFTA Section 12(3) – Who must report and Section 12(4) of the PCMLTFA – Duty to answer and comply.
instruction: Select the topics to learn more about reporting requirements and procedures.

_items.title: Reporting Requirements and Ownership (Real Example)
_items.body:
The following example highlights the consequences of incorrectly seizing currency under the PCMLTFA.

Two foreign nationals arrived at a Canadian land border. The travellers were referred to secondary for a multiplicity of indicators.

During the secondary examination, the BSO found a total of $12,000 U.S. in the driver’s possession located in his pant pocket and in his coat on the back seat of the vehicle. The BSO also discovered that the passenger was body packing a total of $9,000 U.S. Once the currency was converted to Canadian dollars, it exceeded the reporting threshold.

During the course of the examination, the driver claimed ownership of all of the currency, and the passenger said that the driver only gave him the money to carry. This resulted in the BSO completing only one seizure for the totality of the undeclared currency ($21,000 U.S.) in the name of the driver. However, the BSO should have completed two seizures regardless of the claim of ownership, as both travellers were in possession of undeclared currency and contravened the law.

Consequently, the seizure was appealed. Following their review, Recourse had no choice, based on legislation, to return a portion of the currency seized ($9,000 U.S. that was body packed on the passenger) because the seizure was taken against the driver who had claimed "ownership". The act says: "possession". As such, two separate seizures should have been completed and cross-referenced. Completed the correct way, both seizures would have been maintained following the Ministerial Review by Recourse.

Taking a Closer Look at Possession

In this example, the seizure was appealed due to the treatment of the term “possession”.

When referring to legislation, [sec. 12(3)] states that the person who is in possession of the currency or monetary instrument is obligated to report. This becomes important when dealing with multiple people within one conveyance or with families.

For example:

A mother, father and 2 children are travelling together, but the mother has a total of $12,000 CAD in her purse. She is required to report the $12K in her possession to the BSO or on the E311 card, regardless if they claim that each family member is the owner of $4,000 CAD each.

Now, if that same family were travelling together and each person had in their possession (on their person, or as part of their separate baggage) $4,000 CAD, then there is no obligation to report as no one individual is in possession of the threshold reporting amount.

 

Possession under the Criminal Code is different from what constitutes possession under the PCMLTFA. Possession is an element common to all offences related to property obtained by crime.

According to subsection 4(3) of the Criminal Code:

(a)a person has anything in possession when he has it in his personal possession or knowingly

(i)has it in the actual possession or custody of another person, or

(ii)has it in any place, whether or not that place belongs to or is occupied by him, for the use or benefit of himself or of another person; and

(b)where one of two or more persons, with the knowledge and consent of the rest, has anything in his custody or possession, it shall be deemed to be in the custody and possession of each and all of them.

As per section 358, the offence of property obtained by crime is complete when the person has, alone or jointly with another person, possession of, or control over, the property or thing, or if the person assists in concealing or disposing of stolen goods.

- Definition as seen in the Criminal Code, Detention, Arrest and Personal Search lesson

_items.title: Reporting Requirements
_items.body:
At primary, every traveller must report the importation of currency or monetary instruments equal to or greater than a value of $10,000 CAD.

At secondary, as per the CBCMIRRs, travellers must submit a written report; the CBSA provides the following forms to facilitate this reporting obligation :

E677 - CROSS BORDER CURRENCY OR MONETARY INSTRUMENTS REPORT - INDIVIDUAL:

The E677 is to be used when an individual crosses the border and is carrying Currency and/or Monetary Instruments which is their own.

E667 - CROSS BORDER CURRENCY OR MONETARY INSTRUMENTS REPORT - GENERAL :

The E667 is used when an individual is carrying Currency and/or Monetary Instruments on behalf of another person or entity, or when sending currency and/or monetary instruments by mail or shipped by courier.

E668 - CROSS BORDER CURRENCY OR MONETARY INSTRUMENTS REPORT MADE BY PERSON IN CHARGE OF CONVEYANCE:

The E668 is used when Currency and/or Monetary Instruments arrives via a commercial carrier (driver) or commercial shipment (cargo) other than postal. In addition, the E668 must be accompanied by an E667.

 

Take a moment to familiarize yourself with the E677, E667,and E668 forms on Atlas.

_items.title: Verification of Currency and Monetary Instruments
_items.body:
The verification process for currency and monetary instruments differs based on whether the items are reported or non-reported. Review the differences below.

Reported Currency and Monetary InstrumentsNon-Reported Currency and Monetary Instruments

If currency or monetary instruments are reported, the BSO may want to verify the declaration.

When possible, the BSO should count the currency/monetary instruments in the presence of another BSO and in front of the traveller. If the declaration is verified and determined to be accurate, no additional action is required.

When non-reported currency or monetary instruments are subject to seizure or forfeiture, the BSO must count it in the presence of another officer.

Upon seizure, the currency and monetary instrument becomes the property of the Crown.

title: Question 2 of 8
body: Currency is considered a good under the Customs Act.
instruction: Select true or false and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. Currency is not a commodity and it is not considered a good under the Customs Act.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. Currency is not a commodity and it is not considered a good under the Customs Act.

title: Question 3 of 8
body: What is the threshold value of currency or monetary instruments that must be reported?
instruction: Select an answer and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. The threshold value for currency or monetary instruments is $10,000 CAD. Once the money is converted to Canadian dollars, if the currency is equal to or greater than $10,000 CAD, the traveller is required by law to report the currency.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. The threshold value for currency or monetary instruments is $10,000 CAD. Once the money is converted to Canadian dollars, if the currency is equal to or greater than $10,000 CAD, the traveller is required by law to report the currency

title: Question 4 of 8
body: How many officers should be involved in conducting a verification count?
instruction: Select an answer and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. Two officers should be involved in conducting a verification count.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. Two officers should be involved in conducting a verification count.

title: Question 5 of 8
body: When currency or monetary instruments equal to or exceeding $10,000 are reported, the BSO may want to verify the declaration. In this instance he or she should:
instruction: Select an answer and select Submit.

_items.text: Ask the traveller to count the currency
Count the currency in an area out of view of the traveller
Count the currency in front of the traveller and, when possible, in the presence of another BSO

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. The BSO should count the currency in front of the traveller, and when possible, in the presence of another BSO.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. The BSO should count the currency in front of the traveller, and when possible, in the presence of another BSO.

title: Question 6 of 8
instruction: Select the appropriate form for each description and select Submit.

_items.text: This form is used when an individual is carrying Currency and/or Monetary Instruments on behalf of another person or entity, or when sending currency and/or monetary instruments by mail.
This form is to be used when an individual crosses the border and is carrying Currency and/or Monetary Instruments which is their own.
This form is used when Currency and/or Monetary Instruments arrives via a commercial carrier (driver) or commercial shipment (cargo) other than postal.

_feedback.correct: That’s Right! You selected the correct response.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response.

title: Question 7 of 8
body: A traveller reports $10,000 CAD cash to be used for the purchase of company equipment. Upon examination of his briefcase, you find an additional $5,000 CAD. What is the amount the traveller should have declared?
instruction: Select an answer and select Submit.

_items.text: Only $10,000 because the additional $ 5,000 is for personal use and is below the threshold.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. The amount the traveller should have declared is $15,000 CAD. The total amount of currency/MI in a person’s possession must be reported; not only what is in excess of the reporting threshold.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. The amount the traveller should have declared is $15,000 CAD. The total amount of currency/MI in a person’s possession must be reported; not only what is in excess of the reporting threshold.

title: Question 8 of 8
body: During a secondary examination, you discover $9,500 U.S in the traveller’s suitcase. Was the traveller required by law to report the currency?
instruction: Select yes or no and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. Once the money is converted to Canadian dollars, the currency is greater than $10,000 CAD.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. Once the money is converted to Canadian dollars, the currency is greater than $10,000 CAD.

title: Levels of Penalty
body: Review the sample ICES seizure reports found in the Resource Tab. Once you are done, read the OB_PRG_2012_57 on report writing and currency seizures.

title: Establishing Proceeds of Crime under Criminal Code
body:
When funds cannot be seized under the PCMLTFA (Currency or monetary instruments have been reported under the PCMLTFA or are under the reporting threshold of CAN $10 000) but BSOs establish reasonable grounds to believe that they are proceeds of crime or terrorist finances, they must contact the Regional Intelligence Office or the IPOC (the Integrated Proceeds of Crime unit-RCMP). The funds could then be seized under sections 83.03, 354, or 462.31 of the Criminal Code.

It’s important to note, seizures under the Criminal Code often involve a lengthy investigation. The physical seizure of the currency normally follows only after such an investigation. The IPOC or the Regional Intelligence office will be able to advise the officer on a case-by-case basis.

title: Level 4 – Suspected Proceeds of Crime
instruction: To learn more about seizing currency for suspected proceeds of crime, select the topics below.

_items.title: PCMLTFA: Level 4
_items.body:
• The CBSA will seize non-reported currency or monetary instruments as forfeit with no terms of release when they are suspected to be proceeds of crime or funds used in terrorist financing activities.
  • Following communication between CBSA Intelligence and the RMCP or local police; the Level 4 seizure can be transferred to the RCMP or police in situations where they feel criminal proceedings can be taken on the funds and used as evidence.
  • When funds are transferred to the RCMP or responding police agency, officers must document the steps followed and provide the transferring details including a copy of the Exhibit Control Form (K129) via email to the Traveller Programs Directorate HQ
 

The RCMP or local police may not attend all Level 4 PCMLTFA currency seizures, as such, the funds are to be transferred to the Public Services and Procurement Canada (PSPC), as per the established procedures.

_items.title: Reasonable Grounds to Believe or Suspect
_items.body:
When seizing suspected proceeds of crime, BSOs must determine if the enforcement action will be carried out under the authority of the PCMLTFA.

The first step is to assess if there was an infraction to the PCMLTFA:

  • The funds are equal to or over the reporting threshold ($10,000); AND
  • They were not declared to the CBSA

If both of these criteria are met and there are reasonable grounds to suspect that the funds are proceeds of crime, the officer will seize the funds at Level 4, with no terms of release.

Reasonable Grounds to Believe

An officer must have reasonable grounds to believe there was a contravention of the PCMLTFA (non-report of currency and MI equal to or greater than $10,000 CAD)

 

Seizure under PCMLTFA at levels 1-3 (terms of release) or level 4*.

Reasonable Grounds to Suspect

*For a level 4 seizure under the PCMLTFA, an officer must have reasonable grounds to suspect that the currency or MI was used for proceeds of crime or terrorist financing.

 

Seizure under the PCMLTFA at level 4 (no terms of release).

 

A reasonable suspicion is not arbitrary nor random; it is based on relevant indicators. Mere suspicion without an articulable reason is not enough; however, your experience coupled with a multiplicity of indicators of money laundering or terrorist financing would be sufficient.

_items.title: Proceeds of Crime Example
_items.body:
A traveller arrives at Prescott POE, at 2:30 am. At PIL, when the BSO asks the question regarding currency or monetary instruments equal or greater to $10,000 CAD, the traveller hesitates and answers: “I have nothing to declare.” Throughout the primary interview, he avoids eye contact and taps his steering wheel. The BSO also notices a box of elastic bands in the back seat of the car.

The BSO refers the traveller to secondary to verify his declaration. At secondary, the BSO conducts a vehicle examination, and discovers five rolls (bundles) of money each containing $5,000 CAD. The rolls were hidden in several places in the vehicle, including in a suitcase. A total of $25,000 CAD was concealed in the vehicle. Once the currency was discovered, the BSO immediately contacted the regional IO to advise them of the situation. The IO informed the BSO that he will not be questioning the traveller but would like him to complete an ORS.

The BSO seized the currency under the PCMLTFA (Level 4 penalty). A K19C in ICES must be completed for the seizure and the traveller is allowed to enter Canada. Once the traveller left the POE, the BSO completed an ORS to provide information to the Intelligence Division.

Applying PCMLTFA

Since the currency was not reported, it was a violation of the PCMLTFA. Therefore, you would seize with no terms of release (Level 4) under the PCMLTFA because the currency was not reported and that you have reasonable grounds to suspect that the currency is proceeds of crime

Furthermore, It is good practice to consult with your regional IO for all Level 4 seizures; the IO may still place a call to the RCMP to see if they have any interest in pursuing an additional investigation under the CC.

_items.title: Arrest
_items.body:
Persons who fail to properly report currency or monetary instruments will not be arrested for a contravention of the PCMLTFA, regardless of whether or not the seized currency or monetary instruments are suspected proceeds of crime. Failure to properly report currency or monetary instruments is a civil offence.

In the event that you suspect that the traveller is in possession of currency for money laundering and terrorist financing purposes, do not arrest the traveller. You should contact your regional intelligence officers and/or complete an ORS report in order for the Intelligence Division to conduct further analysis within the CBSA intelligence cycle.

 

The PCMLTFA does not provide any arrest authorities to the CBSA as the non-report of  currency or monetary instruments is a civil offence. Additionally, within s.2 of the Criminal Code, BSOs are not given peace officer status in relation to the PCMLTFA.

title: Establishing Proceeds of Crime under Criminal Code
body:
An arrest for laundering proceeds of crime will only occur under the guidance of the IPOC unit or Regional Intelligence office. Should the circumstance warrant, an arrest would be made under the authority of subsection 495(1) of the Criminal Code. Only a designated officer at a designated port of entry may make the arrest. The designated officer may only detain an individual for a short period until custody can be transferred to the police

 

Take a moment to read the EN Manual Part 2, Chapter 2 section Establishing Proceeds of Crime Criteria Under the Criminal Code.

For more information, please refer to :

  • Part 6, Chapter 1 (Arrest and Detention) of the Enforcement Manual.
  • CC Section 83.01 - providing, making available, etc., property or services for terrorist purposes
  • CC Section 354 – possession of property obtained by crime
  • CC Section 462.31 - laundering proceeds of crime
  • Enforcement Manual - Part 2, Chapter 2: Cross-Border Currency and Monetary Instruments Reporting; paragraphs 206-208

title: Seizures under the Criminal Code
body:
The BSO will seize the funds under the Criminal Code as proof ONLY if the IPOC-RCMP is prepared to take possession of the currency or monetary instruments and also if there is a clear indication that charges will be brought against the individual.

All currency/monetary instruments seized under the Criminal Code must be recorded on an E352-Evidence Seizure Receipt. The E352 will be given to the person from whom the currency was seized as a receipt.

The K129, the Evidence Control Form, will be completed in order to transfer evidence from the BSO to IPOC-RCMP.

When transferring monetary instruments to the RCMP or other police agency, all documentation used to facilitate the transfer should be noted in the ICES seizure entry.

title: Seizures under the Criminal Code
body:
Should the IPOC-RCMP not attend, the funds must be released back to the person or entity. The CBSA may not seize the funds in question but may complete an ORS to CBSA Intelligence.

 

For more information refer to Enforcement Manual - Part 2, Chapter 2: Cross-Border Currency and Monetary Instruments Reporting; Paragraphs 209-213.

title: Seizures under the Criminal Code - Scenario
body: Based on your understanding of seizures under the criminal code, determine what you would do in the following scenario.
instruction: Select the card to uncover the answer.

_items.front:
At the PIL for land mode a traveller answers "no" to the question regarding currency/monetary instruments. The traveller is sent to secondary examination due to multiplicity of indicators and the BSOs found CAN $9,500 in bills.

What is the best course of action?

back.title: Answer:
back.body:
You do not have the authority to seize the funds under the PCMLTFA as the CAN $10,000 threshold is not attained.

If you have reasonable grounds to suspect that the funds are proceeds of crime, contact your Regional Intelligence office for more information regarding the traveller and complete a ORS report.

If you have reasonable grounds to believe that the funds are proceeds of crime (based on a multiplicity of indicators and presence of contraband), contact your Regional Intelligence office who will then communicate with the RCMP.

title: Question 3 of 6
body: What level of penalty would you apply under the PCMLTFA, if you discover $15,000 CAD of undeclared currency that is hidden in a vehicle’s secret compartment with no indicators that would lead you to suspect proceeds of crime?
instruction: Select an answer and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. A level 3 penalty would apply.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. A level 3 penalty would apply.

title: Question 2 of 6
body: When currency has been properly reported to the CBSA, what legislation authorizes the RCMP to seize the currency as proceeds of crime?
instruction: Select an answer and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. When the currency was reported, only the Criminal Code allows the RCMP to seize currency on reasonable grounds to suspect money laundering or terrorist financing.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct answer. When the currency was reported, only the Criminal Code allows the RCMP to seize currency on reasonable grounds to suspect money laundering or terrorist financing.

title: Question 4 of 6
body: "In the event of a currency or monetary instrument seizure that carries a prescribe penalty, is the traveller obligated to pay the penalty?"
instruction: Select yes or no and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. The traveller does not have to pay the penalty. If the traveller doesn’t pay the penalty, he will need to abandon the currency or monetary instruments.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. The traveller does not have to pay the penalty. If the traveller doesn’t pay the penalty, he will need to abandon the currency or monetary instruments.

title: Question 5 of 6
body: If a Level 4 currency seizure is warranted, the BSO has the authority to arrest the traveller under the Criminal Code.
instruction: Select true or false and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. Persons who fail to properly report currency or monetary instruments will not be arrested for violations of the PCMLTFA or the Criminal Code, regardless of whether or not the seized currency or monetary instruments are suspected proceeds of crime.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. Persons who fail to properly report currency or monetary instruments will not be arrested for violations of the PCMLTFA or the Criminal Code, regardless of whether or not the seized currency or monetary instruments are suspected proceeds of crime.

title: Question 6 of 6
body: If there is reasonable grounds to suspect the currency is for money laundering purposes, a Level 3 penalty would apply.
instruction: Select true or false and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. If you have reasonable grounds to suspect money laundering, a Level 4 penalty would apply.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. If you have reasonable grounds to suspect money laundering, a Level 4 penalty would apply.

title: Indicators of Money Laundering
body:
Travellers may exhibit indicators when crossing the border with money laundering intentions. Review these indicators below.

Traveller

  • Possesses knowledge of reporting requirements
  • Has a low paying job or claims to be self-employed
  • Previous problems with law enforcement
  • Admitted drug use
  • Has gambling debts or financial problems
  • Frequents casinos
  • Travel to source countries or tax haven countries
  • Fails to provide documents related to the claimed source of the money
  • Previous criminality (e.g. trafficking, drug charges, criminal activity/associations, etc.)
  • Previous seizures under the PCMLTFA
  • Drug contamination on luggage
  • Possession of masking agent

Currency

  • Currency concealed in secret compartments
  • Additional currency located on the person
  • Denies knowledge or possession of the currency
  • Attempts to distance themselves from the currency
  • Unable to explain source or use of the funds
  • Mix of denominations in one bundle
  • Bills are disorganized throughout the bundle
  • Rubber bands used to bundle
  • “Wrap” bundling – bill folded over a bundle to separate

title: Indicators of Money Laundering
body:
Smuggling currency by means of swallowing and/or insertion has become a trend. This technique should be kept in mind when questioning travellers.

 

Take a moment to read the OB_PRG_2012_58 Suspected Proceeds of Crime Indicator Guidelines.

title: Additional Questions
body: Please refer to the Resources section for a job aid on additional questions.

title: Additional Questions
body: Additional questions should be asked to the traveller when currency has not been reported.
instruction: Take a look at the example below, then select the arrows to view the additional questions.
mobileInstruction: Take a look at the example below, then select the arrows to view the additional questions.

_items.title: Example
_items.body: A traveller is over-talkative about their trip. Upon searching their vehicle, you discover $20,000 under the passenger seat of the car.

_items.title: Questions to ask the traveller:
_items.body:
• Are you employed?
  • How much do you make?
  • Where are you going?
  • Where are you coming from?
  • Tell me about the ownership of the vehicle?  (leased, rented, 3rd party – get ownership)
  • Do you have any bank cards, credit cards, debit cards?  (check pockets, wallet, and vehicle for bank receipts)
  • Why do you carry so much money instead of using banks/wire transfers? (notate all bank documents found on them – debit cards, credit cards)
  • Do you have a criminal record?
  • Are you involved in criminal activity?
  • Is this money linked to criminal activity?

_items.title: Questions to ask about the money
_items.body:
• In addition to the money I have found, how much money are you also carrying?
  • Why did you conceal the money?
  • Did you count it?
  • If you did not count it, how do you know how much money you are carrying?
  • Whose money is this?  If not theirs, who owns it?
  • What is the source of the money?  Where did it come from? (get specifics)
  • Are you carrying this money for anyone else? If so, tell me about the relationship with this person?
  • Were you paid to carry this money?  How much?
  • What is the money going to be used for? (get specifics)
  • Is this money linked to criminal activity?
  • How is it bundled? (Have them describe it to you)
  • Why is it bundled this way?
  • Who bundled it?
_items.strapline: Questions to ask about the money

title: Indicators of Bulk Cash Smuggling, at POE
body:
Bulk cash smuggling across an international border is a common form of money laundering. It involves physically smuggling cash to another jurisdiction and depositing it in a financial institution, such as an offshore bank, with greater bank secrecy or less rigorous money laundering enforcement. The money can be concealed on a person, in any conveyance, article of luggage, merchandise, container, vehicle, etc.

In cases of bulk cash smuggling, the BSO can conduct, when authorized, a personal search under section 15 of the PCMLTFA.

 

Take a moment to read section 15 of the PCMLTFA which can be found in your Officer Reference Booklet.

title: Indicators of Bulk Cash Smuggling, at POE
instruction: Select the image to view what was smuggled.

title: Indicators of Bulk Cash Smuggling, at POE
body: The act of not declaring cash or monetary instruments of $10,000 CAD may be an indicator of money laundering or terrorist financing $10,000 CAD is a very high threshold. If you discover $10,000 CAD on the traveller or in/on the traveller’s belongings, you should ask the traveller additional questions to see if they can provide a legitimate account for the currency in their possession.

title: Indicators of Bulk Cash Smuggling, at POE
body: It is not the role of the BSO to determine if the currency is legitimate. However, asking additional questions in relation to the discovered funds will enable you to apply the appropriate level of seizure. It is still up to the traveller/entity to prove that the funds are not illicit.

title: Evidence Handling Bulk Currency
instruction: Select the steps to learn about evidence handling procedures for bulk currency.

_items.title: Step 1
_items.body: Once bulk currency is found and its general appearance leads you to think it’s proceeds of crime – STOP and get an assisting officer!

_items.title: Step 2
_items.body: Follow SOPs for significant seizures.

_items.title: Step 3
_items.body: Take a photo of the currency in the place where it was found, before removing it, and notate it in your Officer Notebook.

_items.title: Step 4
_items.body: Take accurate notes on exactly where the money was found (i.e. bundle found inside the vehicle manual in the glove box / wrap of bills located in the subject’s front left pant pocket).

_items.title: Step 5
_items.body: The way cash is bundled can provide evidence that it is proceeds of crime.  Leave it as-is (in a secure location) and call Intelligence Office, prior to dismantling any of the bundles. The RCMP may want all the evidence left in its exact state until they arrive.

title: Indicators of Terrorist Financing
body:
As mentioned previously, when currency is seized and reasonable grounds exist to suspect that it is terrorist financing, it is to be seized under Level 4 with no terms of release.

As per subsection 18(2) of the PCMLTFA, the officer shall, on payment of the penalty in the prescribed amount, return the seized currency or monetary instruments to the individual from whom they were seized or to the lawful owner, unless the officer has reasonable grounds to suspect that the currency or monetary instruments are proceeds of crime within the meaning of subsection 462.3(1) of the Criminal Code or funds used for the financing of terrorist activities.

The following indicators of terrorist financing can be observed and acted upon at POE.

Source countries

Terrorism literature in their luggage

Lookout for Terrorism (GCMS/ICES)

Terrorist financing

Tattoos

Use of false identification

The sudden conversion of financial assets to a virtual currency.

Client provides multiple variations of name, address, phone number or additional identifiers.

The individual/entity may be relevant to a law enforcement and/or national security investigation.

Charitable activity in areas of conflict (i.e. Syria)

 

Please refer to the Resources section for a job aid on terrorist financing indicators.

title: Question 2 of 5
body: To be considered bulk cash smuggling, the currency must be concealed on the person.
instruction: Select true or false and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. The money can be concealed on a person, in any conveyance, article of luggage, merchandise, container, vehicle, etc.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. The money can be concealed on a person, in any conveyance, article of luggage, merchandise, container, vehicle, etc.

title: Question 3 of 5
body: The act of not declaring currency or monetary instruments of $10,000 CAD or greater may be an indicator of money laundering or terrorist financing.
instruction: Select true or false and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. The act of non-declaring currency of a value of $10,000 CAD or greater could be an indicator of money laundering or terrorist financing, but you would require other indicators to have reasonable grounds to suspect proceeds of crime or terrorist financing.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. The act of non-declaring currency of a value of $10,000 CAD or greater could be an indicator of money laundering or terrorist financing, but you would require other indicators to have reasonable grounds to suspect proceeds of crime or terrorist financing.

title: Question 4 of 5
body: If you discover $10,000 CAD on the traveller or in/on the traveller’s belongings, you should not ask additional questions before seizing the currency.
instruction: Select true or false and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. In order to determine the seizure level, additional questions should be asked to negate any suspicion of proceeds of crime.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. In order to determine the seizure level, additional questions should be asked to negate any suspicion of proceeds of crime.

title: Question 5 of 5
body: If bulk currency is found and its general appearance leads you to believe it’s proceeds of crime, you should continue your examination before getting an assisting officer.
instruction: Select true or false and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. You should stop your examination and get an assisting officer, before continuing your examination.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. You should stop your examination and get an assisting officer, before continuing your examination.

title: Question 1 of 5
body: At secondary, which form would you have the traveller complete?
instruction: Select an answer and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. The traveller would have to complete the E677 – Individual form.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. The traveller would have to complete the E677 – Individual form.

title: Question 2 of 5
body: Since the traveller declared a large amount of money, you want to conduct a verification count. Should you get an assisting officer to count the money with you?
instruction: Select yes or no and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. You should get an assisting officer, as per paragraph 164 of the EN Manual Part 2, Chapter 2.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. You should get an assisting officer, as per paragraph 164 of the EN Manual Part 2, Chapter 2.

title: Question 3 of 5
body: Can the traveller be present when you count the money?
instruction: Select yes or no and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. The currency was declared at PIL in accordance with section 12(1) of the PCMLTFA regulations; therefore the traveller may watch while the currency is counted and verified, as per paragraph 164 of the EN Manual Part 2, Chapter 2.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. The currency was declared at PIL in accordance with section 12(1) of the PCMLTFA regulations; therefore the traveller may watch while the currency is counted and verified, as per paragraph 164 of the EN Manual Part 2, Chapter 2.

title: Question 4 of 5
body: In this case, the Officer may use his own discretion as to whether a conveyance examination is warranted for a compliant traveller.
instruction: Select true or false and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. Normal customs procedures still apply. The Officer may use his own discretion as to whether a conveyance examination is warranted for a compliant traveller.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. . The Officer may use his own discretion as to whether a conveyance examination is warranted for a compliant traveller.

title: Question 5 of 5
body: The verification count of the currency and conveyance showed no discrepancies. Is the traveller now free to leave?
instruction: Select yes or no and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. The traveller is free to leave, as he complied with all sections of the PCMLTFA.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. The traveller is free to leave, as he complied with all sections of the PCMLTFA.

title: Intro
body:
Case Study 1:
The Gambler

Case Study 2:
On Holidays

Case Study 3:
Odd Couple

Case Study 4:
Dark Intentions

_graphic.alt: Worried man in car with window down

title: Case Study 2: On Holidays
body: A BSO, working at a PIL booth, conducts a primary interview with a U.S. traveller at the Douglas POE, in Vancouver BC. The traveller claims he is coming to Canada for a one week vacation. When the BSO asks the currency and monetary instruments question, the traveller looks away and then, hesitates before responding: “No”.

title: Question 1 of 5
body: What would you do in this case?
instruction: Select refer or release and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. You should refer the traveller as he seems hesitant when answering the currency and monetary instruments question and his body language indicates avoidance.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. You should refer the traveller as he seems hesitant when answering the currency and monetary instruments question and his body language indicates avoidance.

title: Question 3 of 5
body: Should you count the money in front of the traveller?
instruction: Select yes or no and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. You should not count the money in front of the traveller, as he did not declare the currency initially at PIL.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. You should not count the money in front of the traveller, as he did not declare the currency initially at PIL.

title: Question 2 of 5
body:
A pocket search reveals a total of $9,553.42 U.S., which corresponds to the amount on the bank receipt withdrawal with today’s date that you found on the dashboard, during the vehicle examination.

You then ask him why he did not declare the money when he saw the first officer. He says: “I don’t know why, but the money is for outstanding mortgage payments on my mother’s house.”

A copy of a letter from the U.S. bank in the traveller’s possession confirms that the bank is going to foreclose on his mother’s house, if the mortgage payments are left unpaid. The total mortgage payment due is equal to approximately $9,000 U.S.

You conduct a systems check in ICES and the traveller has no previous PCMLTFA seizures.

After consulting with the Superintendent, do you think that a seizure action is warranted?
instruction: Select yes or no and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. A seizure action is warranted.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. A seizure action is warranted.

title: Question 4 of 5
body: What level of seizure is warranted?
instruction: Select an answer and select Submit.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right! You selected the correct response. Level 1 seizure ($250) because:

  • The traveller did not conceal the currency (pocket normal place to find currency).
  • Admitted to the reason for having the money and this was confirmed by a letter found in the traveller’s possession.
  • Did not have any previous enforcement under PCMLTFA.
  • The officer has no reasonable grounds to suspect the money is proceeds of crime.
  • Currency was not reported at primary. Subsection 12(1) of the PCMLTFA and regulations were circumvented. The regulations state that every person and entity shall report to an Officer the importation or exportation of currency or monetary instruments of a value equal to or greater than $10,0000 CAD.
  • Only after he was shown the bank receipt did he admit to have currency on his person.
  • Currency  is seized under subsection 18 (1) of the PCMLTFA.

_incorrect.final:
You did not select the correct response. Level 1 seizure ($250) because:

  • The traveller did not conceal the currency (pocket normal place to find currency).
  • Admitted to the reason for having the money and this was confirmed by a letter found in the traveller’s possession.
  • Did not have any previous enforcement under PCMLTFA.
  • The officer has no reasonable grounds to suspect the money is proceeds of crime.
  • Currency was not reported at primary. Subsection 12(1) of the PCMLTFA and regulations were circumvented. The regulations state that every person and entity shall report to an Officer the importation or exportation of currency or monetary instruments of a value equal to or greater than $10,0000 CAD.
  • Only after he was shown the bank receipt did he admit to have currency on his person.
  • Currency is seized under subsection 18 (1) of the PCMLTFA.

title: Question 5 of 5
body: Can the traveller pay the penalty using the seized money?
instruction: Select yes or no and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. The traveller can’t use the seized money. Once the currency has been seized, it becomes property of the Crown. The traveller must pay by credit card or other means. After the seizure is done in ICES, a TEPS receipt is generated. Don’t forget, once the seizure penalty is paid the traveller still has to complete and sign the CBCR Report in order to bring in the currency, as per subsection 12(4) of the PCMLTFA.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. The traveller can’t use the seized money. Once the currency has been seized, it becomes property of the Crown. The traveller must pay by credit card or other means. After the seizure is done in ICES, a TEPS receipt is generated. Don’t forget, once the seizure penalty is paid the traveller still has to complete and sign the CBCR Report in order to bring in the currency, as per subsection 12(4) of the PCMLTFA.

title: Intro
body:
Case Study 1:
The Gambler

Case Study 2:
On Holidays

Case Study 3:
Odd Couple

Case Study 4:
Dark Intentions

_graphic.alt: Couple in car with window down

title: Case Study 3: Odd Couple
body:
A BSO, working at the Chopaka POE in Vancouver, is conducting a primary interview with two U.S. citizens. They are claiming to be boyfriend and girlfriend, and state that they are coming to Canada for one day to visit a friend. They declare two cartons of cigarettes. The BSO refers the travellers to secondary for them to pay the applicable duties and taxes on the second carton of cigarettes.

During the vehicle examination, you observe several body language indicators displayed by both travellers: avoiding eye contact when responding questions, shifting weight from side to side and constantly moving their feet.

Upon opening one of the trunk compartments of the van, you find a total of 3 bundles of U.S. currency. A quick scan of the bundles reveal that they all contain $5 U.S. bills.

title: Question 1 of 3
body: Has Section 12(1) of the PCMLTFA been contravened?
instruction: Select yes or no and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. Subsection 12(1) has been contravened because once the money is converted to Canadian dollars, the currency is greater than $10,000 CAD, and the currency was not reported.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. Subsection 12(1) has been contravened because once the money is converted to Canadian dollars, the currency is greater than $10,000 CAD, and the currency was not reported.

title: Question 2 of 3
body: What level of seizure is warranted?
instruction: Select an answer and select Submit.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right! You selected the correct response. This is a Level 2 seizure ($2,500) because:

  • The male traveller attempted to circumvent the reporting obligations of the PCMLTFA and its regulations through concealment other than by means of using a false compartment in a conveyance, or by making false statements.
  • He did not have any previous enforcement under PCMLTFA.
  • The officer has no reasonable grounds to suspect the money is proceeds of crime.

_incorrect.final:
You did not select the correct response. This is a Level 2 seizure ($2,500) because:

  • The male traveller attempted to circumvent the reporting obligations of the PCMLTFA and its regulations through concealment other than by means of using a false compartment in a conveyance, or by making false statements.
  • He did not have any previous enforcement under PCMLTFA.
  • The officer has no reasonable grounds to suspect the money is proceeds of crime.

title: Question 3 of 3
body: Does the traveller have to pay the penalty?
instruction: Select yes or no and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. The male traveller doesn’t have to pay the penalty. If the traveller does not pay the penalty, the currency will remain under customs seizure as per subsection 18(2) of the PCMLTFA and e forfeited to the Crown.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. The male traveller doesn’t have to pay the penalty. If the traveller does not pay the penalty, the currency will remain under customs seizure as per subsection 18(2) of the PCMLTFA and e forfeited to the Crown.

title: Intro
body:
Case Study 1:
The Gambler

Case Study 2:
On Holidays

Case Study 3:
Odd Couple

Case Study 4:
Dark Intentions

_graphic.alt: Senior couple in car with window down

title: Case Study 4: Dark Intentions
body: A BSO is working at a PIL booth, at the Rainy River POE, in Ontario. Two travellers arrive from the U.S.; both the male and female traveller are U.S. citizens. They claim they are family-related (brother and sister-in-law) and are coming to Canada for the weekend to attend their niece’s wedding. The male traveller declares $12,000 U.S. He mentions that the money is a wedding gift for his niece and her fiancé to help them with their down payment on their new home. The man is very talkative and you have a hard time to make him stop talking. The female traveller is sitting in the back seat of the car and avoids eye contact during the entire primary interview.

title: Question 1 of 8
body: In this case, would you refer the travellers to secondary?
instruction: Select yes or no and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. You would refer the travellers to secondary as a E677-Individual report must be completed.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. You would refer the travellers to secondary as a E677-Individual report must be completed.

title: Question 2 of 8
body:
At secondary, you provide the E677 – Individual Form to the male traveller to declare his $12,000 in writing. While he is completing the form, you notice him bending over to pick up money that is falling out of his bulgy and baggy pant leg. You also notice some indicators namely: he is very talkative in an attempt to distract you and speaks on behalf of his sister-in-law.

Based on the indicators present, you decide to conduct a cursory vehicle examination. During the examination, the male traveller becomes fidgety; he keeps playing with his declaration form. You also notice that the female traveller is wearing bulky clothes and her shirt is a bit oversized. You do not find any other indicators, currency or contraband in the baggage nor in the vehicle, but you have reasonable grounds to suspect they are hiding something on their person.

Based on the indicators present, is a frisk warranted?
instruction: Select yes or no and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. A frisk would be warranted because there is a multiplicity of indicators. You have reasonable grounds to believe the travellers are concealing currency on their person.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. . A frisk would be warranted because there is a multiplicity of indicators. You have reasonable grounds to believe the travellers are concealing currency on their person.

title: Question 3 of 8
body:
When you as the travellers what they are hiding underneath their clothing, they refuse to answer.

By asking what they are hiding underneath their clothing, are you reopening primary?
instruction: Select yes or no and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. This is not reopening primary. You are asking a question for health and safety reasons, as you can see there is something hidden under their clothing that may potentially harm you.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. This is not reopening primary. You are asking a question for health and safety reasons, as you can see there is something hidden under their clothing that may potentially harm you.

title: Question 4 of 8
body:
Once in the detention area, you advise the Superintendent on duty of the situation and verbally inform him of your reasonable grounds to suspect an contravention of PCMLTFA has occurred. You therefore ask for approval to conduct a personal search under section 15 of the PCMLTFA.

According to you, do you have enough grounds for a personal search?
instruction: Select yes or no and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. You have reasonable grounds to suspect a contravention of the PCMLTFA has occurred based on multiplicity of indicators.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. You have reasonable grounds to suspect a contravention of the PCMLTFA has occurred based on multiplicity of indicators.

title: Question 5 of 8
body: Identify and select the indicators that would justify your grounds for a personal search.
instruction: Select an answer and select Submit.

_items.text: Male traveller is over-talkative and responds for the female traveller
Refuses to answer question regarding what is concealed under their clothing
Male traveller has money falling from his pant leg
Unusual bulges on the female’s abdomen and on the male’s lower leg

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. All of the indicators would justify your grounds for a personal search.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. All of the indicators would justify your grounds for a personal search.

title: Question 6 of 8
body:
You read the following caution to the travellers:

“I have reasonable grounds to suspect that you are carrying non-reported currency or monetary instruments above the prescribed amount on or about your person and I am detaining you for the purposes of a personal search, as authorized by section 15 of the Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act”

You and the assisting Officer begin the personal search with the female traveller. The personal search reveals that she has currency around her waist. You put all the currency into an evidence bag and seal it while in the search room.

You and the assisting Officer begin the personal search with the male traveller who had money falling from his pant leg. Your personal search reveals more bundles of money taped to his calves. The currency is placed in an evidence bag and sealed while the Officer and traveller are still in the room.

You do queries on:

  • CPIC (Canadian Police Information Centre)
  • NCIC (National Criminal Information Centre)
  • ICES (Integrated Customs Enforcement System)

You find that the male has a warrant for his arrest in Texas on charges of Fraud and possession of counterfeit currency.

Once the travellers are in separate detention area, you begin opening the evidence bags and count the money with the assisting Officer. The total amount of money is $399,880 U.S.

 After you consult with your Superintendent, you call the Intelligence and Contraband Division office. They decide to call the RCMP’s Integrated Proceeds of Crime (IPOC) unit.

Choose the best answer.
instruction: Select an answer and select Submit.

_items.text: Two separate seizures – one taken against each individual who failed to meet the reporting obligation under the PCMLTFA.
Only one seizure with the total amount of $399,880 U.S.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response. As per subsection 12 (3) of the PCMLTFA, two travellers were found to be in contravention of the Act, as such, two separate seizures must be completed.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. As per subsection 12 (3) of the PCMLTFA, two travellers were found to be in contravention of the Act, as such, two separate seizures must be completed.

title: Question 7 of 8
body: What level of seizure would be warranted?
instruction: Select an answer and select Submit.

_feedback.correct: That’s right! You selected the correct response.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response.

title: Question 8 of 8
body:
The following indicators would lead you to have reasonable grounds to suspect the money is proceeds of crime.

  • Refuses to answer question regarding what is concealed under their clothing
  • The currency was concealed on the traveller’s person,
  • The money was not declared
  • The male traveller has outstanding warrant for his arrest in Texas on charges of fraud and possession of counterfeit currency.

True or False?
instruction: Select true or false and select Submit.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right! You selected the correct response. The following indicators would lead you to have reasonable grounds to suspect the money is proceeds of crime.

  • Refuses to answer question regarding what is concealed under their clothing
  • The currency was concealed on the traveller’s person,
  • The money was not declared
  • The male traveller has outstanding warrant for his arrest in Texas on charges of fraud and possession of counterfeit currency

_incorrect.final:
You did not select the correct response. The following indicators would lead you to have reasonable grounds to suspect the money is proceeds of crime.

  • Refuses to answer question regarding what is concealed under their clothing
  • The currency was concealed on the traveller’s person,
  • The money was not declared
  • The male traveller has outstanding warrant for his arrest in Texas on charges of fraud and possession of counterfeit currency

title: Conclusion
body:
Congratulations on completing the Proceeds of Crime: PCMLTFA lesson.

You must confirm in ESS My Learning that you have completed this course:

  1. Close this page to update your completion progress
  2. Click the Confirm Participation link in the Confirm Participation section located at the bottom of the Course Description page

title: Learning Evaluation
body: After you have confirmed your participation, you will receive an email from <DO-NOT-REPLY/NE-PAS-REPONDRE@cra-arc.gc.ca> that contains the learning evaluation form. Please complete the form; your feedback helps ensure that courses and content are up to date and relevant. Thank you.

title: Case Study 3: Odd Couple
body:
You conduct a systems check in ICES and the travellers have no previous PCMLTFA seizures.

You take the currency to a secure area to count it with another Officer. The total value of undeclared currency is $9,000 U.S. A pocket search on both travellers reveals an additional $20 CAD each, and business cards for an exotic dance club in the area.

title: New Component Title
